TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Coarse-loamy, mixed, superactive, frigid Xeric Haplocalcids

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON:  Mathon loamy sand, native grass.  (Colors are for dry soil unless otherwise noted.)
A11--0 to 5 inches; brown (10YR 5/3) loamy sand, very dark grayish brown (10YR 3/2) moist; single grained; loose; many very fine and fine roots; mildly alkaline (pH 7.8); clear wavy boundary.  (3 to 7 inches thick)
B2--5 to 25 inches; brown (10YR 5/3) sandy loam, dark grayish brown (10YR 4/2) moist; weak fine and medium subangular blocky structure; slightly hard, very friable; common very fine and fine roots; many very fine tubular pores; moderately alkaline (pH 8.0); clear wavy boundary.  (5 to 22 inches thick)
C1ca--25 to 27 inches; very pale brown (10YR 7/3) sandy loam, grayish brown (10YR 5/2) moist; moderate fine and medium subangular blocky structure; hard, very friable, slightly plastic; many very fine tubular pores; strongly calcareous; common lime veins and splotches; moderately alkaline (pH 8.2); clear wavy boundary.  (8 to 25 inches thick)
C2ca--37 to 62 inches; pale brown (10YR 6/3) sandy loam, grayish brown (10YR 5/2) moist; massive; slightly hard, very friable, slightly plastic; few very fine roots; many very fine tubular pores; few basalt pebbles and cobbles; strongly calcareous; moderately alkaline (pH 8.2); abrupt and smooth boundary.  (12 to 30 inches thick)
IIR--62 inches, basalt.

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION:  Jefferson County, Idaho; 450 feet south, 150 feet east of the N1/4 corner, sec. 34, T.7N., R.37E.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content:
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:  The mean annual soil temperature ranges from 41 to 46 degrees F.; and the mean summer soil temperature at a depth of 20 inches is about 66 degrees F.  The soils are usually moist, but are dry between depths of 8 and 24 inches for a continuous period of about 45 days in the late summer.  The organic matter content of the upper 15 inches ranges from 1.0 to 2.0 percent.  In some areas, the profile contains up to 10 percent basalt pebbles and cobbles. Bedrock is at depths of 4O to 65 inches.
The A horizon has chroma of 3 or 4 dry.
The B horizon has value of 5 or 6 dry.
The Cca horizon has value of 6, 7 or 8 dry and chroma of 2 or 3 and contains 1 to 10 percent very hard or hard cylindrical nodules of soil material or cicada krotovinas in some pedons.  This horizon is moderately or strongly alkaline (pH 8.2 to 9.0).

COMPETING SERIES.content: COMPETING SERIES:  These are the Granyon, Modkin and Ucopia series.  Granyon soils have a paralithic contact at depths of less than 40 inches.  Modkin soils have basalt bedrock at depths of 20 to 40 inches.  Ucopia soils are neutral throughout the profile.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content: GEOGRAPHIC SETTING:  The soils are on basalt plains at an elevation of about 4,900 feet.  Slopes range from 2 to 20 percent.  The soils formed in moderately coarse textured eolian deposits partially of basaltic origin.  The climate is semiarid with dry summers.  The mean annual precipitation is 8 to 11 inches including 1 to 3 feet of snowfall.  The average freeze-free period is 80 to 115 days.  Maximum precipitation is in May and June.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content: GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS:  These are the Bondranch and Grassy Butte soils and the competing Modkin soils.  Bondranch soils have basalt at depths of 10 to 20 inches.  Grassy Butte soils have loamy sand texture in the 10- to 40-inch control section.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY:  Well drained; slow to medium runoff; moderately rapid permeability.

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION:  Used for range.  The natural vegetation is big sagebrush, rabbitbrush, antelope bitterbrush, needle-and-thread grass, sod wheatgrasses, Indian ricegrass and Nevada bluegrass.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT:  Southeastern Idaho.  The series is of small extent.
